Award.AwardTitle: Global Engineering Competency: Definitions, Development Paths, and Situational Assessment

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will develop a means to measure engineering students' ability to function in a global workforce. The project uses a technique based on situational judgment tests to determine global competence. By creating a means to measure global competence then widely distributing the measurement instrument, the project can help engineering degree programs to develop effective courses and curricula that prepare students for current, global engineering practice.

The broader significance and importance of this project arises through the need of engineering degree programs to develop cost effective ways of preparing students to function in a globalized workforce. By helping program evaluate students' competence, this research can eventually lead to improvements in the US engineering workforce. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by creating results and research that are useful for society by informing educational policy and practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background/Context: As globalization trends intensify, many in the U.S. and abroad agree that engineers and other technical professionals must be ready to work across countries and cultures. In response, companies and universities are working to increase the number of professionals with such capabilities. However, there has been a lack of understanding and agreement about what global competency means for engineers, how it develops, and how it can be measured.

Purpose: To address these gaps, this project had three main goals: 1) define global engineering competency (GEC), 2) create and share instructional content and survey tools that can support development and measurement of global engineering competency, and 3) promote the use of scenario-based approaches to teaching and assessment in engineering education and other fields.

Approach: This project had three main phases. In the first phase, interviews and focus groups were held with more than 25 global engineers to better understand what global competency means for engineers and to collect specific examples of global engineering work. The second phase of the project involved writing situational judgment test (SJT) questions inspired by the collected examples and other source materials (case studies, etc.). The third project phase was focused on using survey data to validate a smaller subset of GEC SJT items and two additional assessment instruments. 

Results: During the first phase of the project the research team identified three dimensions of global engineering competency (technical coordination; engineering cultures; ethics, standards, and regulations) and six national/cultural contexts of interest (China, France, Germany, India, Japan, and Mexico). During the second phase of the project the research team wrote 74 global engineering scenarios covering every combination of dimension and national/cultural context. The scenarios were developed for training and assessment purposes, and select scenarios were piloted in courses and workshops with hundreds of engineering students and professionals. In the third project phase, 6 of the scenarios were taken through a complete cycle of development and validation based on survey data collected from 400 practicing engineers. This final phase also involved continued efforts to develop of two additional surveys, Sojourn Readiness Assessment (SRA) and Global Engineering Competency Scale (GECS), as well as a web-based survey tool called Global Assessment Platform (GAP). 

Conclusions: This project has helped clarify what counts as global engineering competency and how it might be measured, including through creation and deployment of three assessment instruments focused on specific aspects of GEC. More generally, our work highlights how scenario-based and situational approaches can be used to improve instructional and assessment practices in engineering education and other fields. Finally, the project introduced six undergraduate and seven graduate students to new areas of assessment research and practice, and provided one undergraduate and one graduate student with software development experience.
